p: Tropical and subtropical forests are major biodiversity hotspots harbouring many species and are recognised as important global carbon sinks and sources [ 18, 19, 23â€“ 25]. Long-term directional changes in the community composition of tropical forests have been reported recently, and these changes have been attributed to climate change [ 21, 26]. Studies have analysed the effects of climate change on the composition of various plant communities in many areas, including deserts [ 27], grasslands [ 28]and lowland forests [ 29]. Actually, climate-driven impacts on long-term community changes are difficult to disentangle from changes driven by stand development [ 30]. Although, the causes underlying these changes, specifically the contribution of long-term climate change vs. successional recovery from past disturbances, remain debated [ 21]. To increase the accuracy and reliability of the assessment, the community development process should be considered when one examines the effects of climate change on community composition change.
